name: Caleb
comment info:
1) As others have already mentioned, I too noticed that younger generations tend to be more optimistic concerning the future of their country, while adults generally held more negative views. 
In twelve of the twenty one countries surveyed, more than 50% of youths (ages 15-24) believed that the world was becoming a better place. The majority of adults (ages 40 and older) who were surveyed, demonstrated an overall positive mindset in only six of the twenty one countries. Obviously there is a disparity in world view between older and younger generations. 

2) The glaring question is, why do older generations have generally negative outlooks on life while younger generations perceive a brighter future? I wonder what factors contribute to the attitudes of a country’s populace? Bie B. Sea, from Taihu Lake, cited recent economic growth as a potential cause for Indonesia’s largely positive mindset. Others have pointed to societal pressures (for example stresses of the education system) as a reason for more negative mindsets.

name: Rebecca
comment info:
I notice that in general, more younger people ages 15-24 think that the world is getting better with each generation rather than older people ages 40+ do. I find this really interesting because often people think of younger generations as being especially pessimistic and negative, whereas this graph says otherwise.  The US is one of the farthest points away from the line, with a positive residual, meaning that more young people think the world is getting better, and less older people do. I wonder if what the world was like as the older people were growing up shaped how they feel about future generations - they might be negative because newer ideas and concepts that they are not used to are surfacing, and many people do not like change.
I wonder what other countries' data looks like - is there a specific reason that they chose to only survey/include these countries? If they included other countries, this graph might look completely different. I also wonder about the ages in between - how do 25-39 year olds feel about the world?
This relates to me and my community because I am in the younger generation, and I'm surprised at how positive so many young people are, because it often feels like the opposite.

Title: The World - Half Full or Half Empty?

name: Logan AOSE
comment info: In this graph, I see that significantly more amount of young people, 15-24-year-olds, believe the world is getting better with each generation.  Two countries that I immediately notice have large differences between the opinions of the younger and older groups surveyed are the United States and Japan. For the United States, almost 65% of the younger generation believes the world is getting better with each generation while about 35% of the 40+ group believes this. For Japan, about 60% of the 15-24-year-old group believes the world is getting better with each generation while about 25% of the older group believes the prompt. Both countries have such vast changes with the younger groups' beliefs compared to the older. I wonder why these specific two countries have the largest differences. I also wonder why Indonesia's percentages are so high up for both groups, having over 75% for both. This relates to me and my community because my country, the U.S is part of this poll taken and my age is also considered in the graph, so it's interesting to see how my own generations view our progress of bettering the world. A title appropriate for this graph would be "Each Generations' Thoughts on the Bettering of the World."

name: Ben
comment info: In nearly all of the countries surveyed, more young people (aged 15-24) believed the world was getting better than middle aged to older people (ages 40 ). There were no significant outliers that had the opposite relationship. I also noticed that the differential between the two was greatest in countries that had relatively low population growth rates, like the United States and Japan. I learned in my human geography class that relationships like that can end out exacerbating issues for the older dependent population. I wonder if potentially that is one of the reasons why older people tend to have a more pessimistic viewpoint on where society is headed. I also wonder why some countries, like Indonesia, were so overwhelmingly positive in their views across the board, but some countries were overall very negative. I think it likely is influenced by the situation of internal affairs within that country. I’m not familiar with the political systems of each country here, but I think it’s also plausible for that to have a significant impact on people’s world views. This graph could be titled “Is the world improving with the new generation? They think so.”

name: Bie B. Sea
comment info:
The first thing I noticed is how 'Young' people tend to lean towards the idea of "the world is getting better with each generation"  more than 'older' people. As in the graph, you can see that most of the 15 - 24-year-olds in the provided countries fall between the 50-75% range, with none under 25%. However, when looking at the Y-axis for people over the age of 40, most countries fall below 50%, and have a significant amount under 25%. 

There is not exactly a noticeable trend among the data, however you do notice that most of the '1st world' countries have a much higher 'optimistic' younger population than an older one. As you can see in the graph, the US, UK, Japan and Germany are all within the 50-75% range on the X-axis (younger people believing the world is getting better), meanwhile on the Y-axis (Older people believing that the world is getting better) all the previously mentioned countries fall below the 50% mark. 

There is an anomaly within this result, which would be Indonesia, as both the younger and older generations agree that the world is getting better as time goes on. This is likely due to the fact that Indonesia's economy has increased by over 600% since the year 2000, this would obviously see a great increase in the quality of life and general welfare of the populace. Under such conditions, it is quite understandable why Indonesia's population generally have such 'high hopes' for the future.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
@Brady Marquis Thank you for sharing your observations. You ask a couple of great questions in your comments as well.

Let's think about your central question: "I wonder why some countries are really high in 15-24 year olds thinking the owls dis getting better but the 40+ year olds think the world isn’t getting better, why the drastic difference?"

Two ways to analyze this:
1) Find which countries have the greatest difference in optimism between age groups and which countries have the most similar optimism between age groups. Look at the two groups of countries. What could make these countries differ?
2) To get at the "why" behind the generational difference in the United States & your local community, survey classmates and their parents.  Ask the same question as was asked in the survey (see text below the graph).  After they give a yes or no answer, ask for their #1 reason for their answer.  You could compare the statistics you obtain to the countries in the graph.

@Caroline C. This is a great response, with an amazing articulation of what the line represents and what it means to be far above the line or very close to it. 

You also observed a great pattern of more optimism in developing nations, where there may be a faster rate of economic growth. name: Nathan C
comment info:
1. I noticed that out of all of the countries, there were only 3 countries whose adults over 40 years old believe that the world is getting better. But even then, only 45-60% of adults in these countries actually believe this. 

Indonesia is the only country where over 75% of its population of 15-24 year olds things the world is getting better. The rest of the countries' percentage of believers range from anywhere between 25%-75%. 

2. I wonder how human development influenced these results. Around 15-24 years of age, you slowly but surely start to lose your innocence as more terrible aspects of the world become clear. That may be why so few people in that age range actually believe that the world can experience a positive change. The older you get, however, you will witness so many changes since the years you were young, especially technological and medical advancements making life more convenient for others. 

The graph also shows that this works the other way. The greater abundance of countries whose 15yr-24yr population have high faith in the future may have to do with youthful thinking and hope before it gets shattered with more experience (most likely corresponding with more years of living). 

3. The age range of people in my town is a bit over 40 years, and this makes me intrigued to learn more about our ways of thinking and view on if future improvements are feasible. 

4. "Has Hope For Our Future Decreased? Here's 40 Countries' Input for Why and Why Not"

name: Ty Neadik
comment info: This scatter plot, representing the data between two discrete variables with moderate positive correlation, shows how young adults (ages 15-24 years old) are more optimistic than 40+ years old adults. The audience can be psychologists, therapists, counselors, or anyone concerned about mental health, directing them towards pessimistic adults and offering help. The meaning of this plot can mean the world is becoming a better place because present young adults didn’t have to experience as much pain or suffering the 40+ years old adults did when they were younger. Another takeaway could be that older people have learned the negativity in our world through life experiences; hence, they are less optimistic. For instance, young adults could have big or unrealistic dreams and hopes for their future career, lifestyle, income, etc. But as they age, realizing the realities of how the real world works, it's easy to see why the older adults are less optimistic. The purpose of this plot is to compare and contrast how two different groups of people view our world, providing data for anyone interested.

name: Louise Bernice Habarugira
comment info:
I have noticed that this graph is a stacked scatter plot, which consists of participants from 7 African countries, 6 Asian countries, 4 American countries, and 4 European countries. The survey was fairly distributed (based on diversity) in these aspirations of generations bettering the world as time progresses. I have also noticed the lack of 40+ year-old participants, which I perceive as a sign that their opinion is rather less significant in this topic, because their generation has fundamentally passed. I believe that 15–24-year old’s are more reliable in this survey, because they are the current generation and could be considered as people who still have time to take new steps to better the world.  I am genuinely fascinated, and wonder how people respond to this question. What is the criteria of ‘better’? Doesn’t their environment affect the way they perceive the world? Due to this, this graph in my perspective is unreliable, these countries are in completely different circumstances (whether it’s in terms of GDP, environment, health, safety etc.). Therefore, ‘better’ is complete bias. Different standards are incompatible. Coming from myself, a citizen of the poorest country in the world, Burundi, my standards of ‘better’, definitely can’t be similar to the standards of someone from one of the richest countries in the world (USA).  One would benefit from this ‘bettering’ and another may find it as a disadvantage. 

My Headline: IS THE FUTURE ‘BETTER’ FOR EVERYONE?

name: Georgia
comment info: This graph is to show the comparison of young adults (15 to 24-year-olds) and middle-aged adults (40-year-old) and their amount of optimism for the future. The results highlight that the younger generations are much more optimistic about themselves and their future world, whilst the older generation believes that there is little hope for the future. This is concerning as it is worrying that the adults are so negative about our future, possibly meaning that they see a future that younger generations cannot see. I also observed that countries that are lower in socio-economical status and rely more on religion, such as Ethiopia, India and Indonesia, have a significantly higher percentage of young and old generations of adults with beliefs of improvement for our future generations.

The graph clearly shows a larger percentage of people aged 15-24 think the world is getting better. name: Jade
comment info:
Ignorance is Bliss?

 **What do you notice?**

I notice that in general, young people, aged 15-24 are more optimistic about the future than older people aged over 40. In developed countries of greater wealth, the divide between the youth and over 40s is more significant compared to the difference in less wealthy countries. Surprisingly, the quality of life in the countries doesn’t seem to have a clear relationship with the optimism of its people, with several countries that have a large percentage of its people in poverty or in conflict ranking higher than that of the USA, Germany, Japan and France. 

- **What do you wonder?**

I wonder why Indonesian youth adults are so positive about the future in comparison to other countries and whether this has to do with their quality of life, culture and government system. I also wonder what causes people, in general, to become less hopeful for the future when they are older, and whether the hopes of young people are misplaced and a result of naive idealism and the belief that they have the power to change the future for the better. Is it because older people have less faith in the younger generations that they believe that things will get worse?

name: Andy Wu
comment info: [4/5] I wonder if the poll is deemed adequately convincing since the 1,000 respondents on average from each country represent only a tiny portion of the countries’ total population. One thousand people out of the U.K.’s 67 million people is a mere 0.0015%, which cannot precisely tell what the people of the U.K. generally think about this question. In addition, these interviews are not done in person or through video chats, but through telephone calls, which means that respondents don't have to take it seriously. This further takes away the credibility of the polls. While we could argue that covering 1,000 respondents from every country is still a pretty large sample size since it’s not possible to cover everybody or interview everybody in person, we should still leave our doubts on the credibility of the polls. In addition, the poll was asking respondents to address what they think regarding the entire world, but most people might only think about their own country, because that’s what matters most to them and that’s what they care about, but what they think about their own countries do not necessarily have a relationship with whether or not the world is getting better. This potential loophole could also adulterate the authenticity and relevance of the survey results regarding the question. But despite all these accounts, this was still an interesting survey that is worthy of noting and further researching.

name: Andy Wu
comment info: [2/5] Overall, the number of global and regional crises did not fall but rather got bigger after the Cold War ended in 1991 when a new world order originally endowed with hope was established. Adults who are aged more than 40 have had enough of these havocs, and they have been hoping that things will gradually settle down when the U.S.S.R. collapsed. However, the exact opposite has happened. The disappointment is huge, and so did the hope of having a nonviolent world drop. This should happen to be the answer to why adults aged more than 40 are generally more pessimistic about the current world than young adults aged between 15 to 24 in the poll. These young adults grew up in the best of times with pervasive high-end technologies and democracies, so they have no idea what the quadragenerians have lived through in their childhood and adolescence, which was an era dominated by political animosity between Western democracies and Eastern communist dictatorships, giving rise to a myriad of global conflicts. That explains why younger adults have generally more positive thoughts on the world’s status quo.

name: Andy Wu
comment info: [3/5] The second thing I noticed is that there isn’t a clear cause-and-effect relationship between a country’s status quo and the percentage of people in that country who think the world is getting better. Let’s take Brazil and India, who have both been involved in unpleasant domestic situations for the past decade, where Brazil has been struggling to keep the Amazon Rainforest sustainable since the wildfire disaster occurred in 2019, and India has one of the worst covid-19 pandemic situations in the world as of 2021. While both Brazil and India seem to be going through a very rough time, there’s a surprisingly huge gap between the number of Brazilians in the poll who deems that the world has gone better and the number of Indians who deems that the world has gone better. For Brazil, less than 30% of young adults and less than 25% of adults expressed optimism about the world’s status quo, compared to poll takers from India, where more than 60% of young adults and adults expressed optimism about the world’s status quo. Not only India but also countries such as the U.S., Ukraine, and Lebanon have also undergone rough times in recent years, but have more than half of its respondents expressed positive views regarding the poll question. This is an interesting phenomenon that is worthy of further investigation.

name: Andy Wu
comment info: [1/5] The first thing I noticed is the sharp variance between the percentage of adults and young adults who think the world is becoming better where the former age group has a more negative view regarding the issue than the latter age group for 18 of the 21 countries selected for the poll. In my opinion, this discrepancy happens because adults who are older than 40-year-old have more knowledge and experience about how the world has changed over the past half-century, as to young adults who have only witnessed the change over the past one or two decades, so older adults usually possess more visual and tangible opinions to whether or not the world is getting better with each generation. In the contemporary world, we are facing many crises ranging from the most urgent public health concerns such as the Ebola Outbreak, the exacerbating HIV/AIDS epidemics, and the worldwide covid-19 pandemic, to wars and unrests such as fighting and skirmishes in Afghanistan, Iraq, and Ukraine, political mayhems embroiling over Myanmar, Egypt, Hong Kong, Algeria, Pakistan, Afghanistan, Iran, Iraq, the United States, the United Kingdom, as well as the surging cases of terrorist attacks and hate crimes all over the world both in developing countries and developed countries, and finally to an increased number of natural disasters caused by global warming and the cumulative over-exploitation of the environment, such as forest fires in the Amazon rainforest, Australian desert, and Taiwan.

name: Andy Wu
comment info:
[5/5] This graph provides survey data about the percentage of young adults aged between 15 to 24 and the percentage of adults aged 40+ who think the world is becoming a better place with each generation. Although not covering an ample sample size, it can serve as a possible answer to questions we might have about changes in the world over the past quarter of a century. Based on this piece of data and our knowledge of what’s happening around the globe right now, we can take a rough guess at the status quos of each country on the survey list. This can help us to understand the world better through the voice of citizens of each country, while we should leave our doubts on the accuracy of the survey results since insignificant sample size is not very convincing for us to come to a definitive conclusion.

Based off of the topic of the survey and the graph, a catchy headline could be:

SURVEY SHOWS PERCENTAGE OF PEOPLE IN 21 COUNTRIES WHO EXPRESS OPTIMISM ABOUT THE WORLD

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Andy Wu --

You take the prize for the length of your analysis.  The points you bring up about why some countries are more optimistic than others and why youth tend to be more optimistic than adults are very appropriate.  In addition to political conflicts and environmental conditions, you may want to consider the countries’ economies, education attainment and opportunities to advance.  

Regarding the sample size, this is a major topic in studying statistical inference.  (This is a study using inference since we are trying to infer what the population thinks from a sample.)  You may want to search online for an introduction to sample size determination. Quite surprisingly, if the sample is randomly chosen (each member of the population is equally probable to be selected), a sample of size of about 1,000 is considered adequate for any population size.  

Please go to the UNICEF interactive site “The Changing Childhood.”  (UNICEF sponsored this international, intergenerational study.)  There you can answer some of the questions that were asked of the about 21,000 people.  Also, there is a link to the report with many more findings and an explanation of how the survey was executed.

name: Carolyn
comment info:
What I notice:
It is apparent that in most of the countries, 15-to 24-year-olds people are more likely to satisfy with the progress of improving the world than 40+year-olds people. The countries located close to the black line like Indonesia, India, Nigeria, Bangladesh, Morocco, and Mali have relatively less difference in thoughts between generations. Overall, relatively fewer people in Brazil, and Mali are satisfied with the world, and have a hopeful view of the future, whereas people in Indonesia are more hopeful about the progress for the past few years no matter which generation they’re in. Also, the countries possessing a higher percentage of satisfaction regardless of generation are not fully developed countries. The developed countries that lead the world’s economy are mostly located in the middle part like the US, Germany, the UK.
 
What I wonder: 
I wonder about the specific structure or environment of a country that impacts people to build the view of the society. For example, I wonder how the society in the United States influences the younger generation to get a positive view of the world, whereas the older generation tends to view the future negatively though they’re living at the same time.

Relation to my community:
As the graph shows, the society that I spent most of my lives in had a more positive view of the world among the younger generation, rather than 40+.

 A catchy headline that captures the graph’s main idea:
Is the world indeed getting better?

I wonder if age has to do with the results. I wonder why countries like Brazil and Mali are less optimistic than countries like Indonesia. This graph relates to me because I fall into the younger age group and I do believe that new generations do better the world especially when you think about how much people fought for their rights. Young people's optimism!

replies.comment info:

name: Luis Sandoval
comment info: I noticed that Indonesia had the highest percentage that said the world is getting better while Brazil and Mali were the lowest. I also noticed that far more 15 to 24 year old's said the world is getting better than those who are +40 years old. I wonder if the reason Mali and Brazil percentage is low because of the areas where they live and that influences their decisions. replies.comment info:
Hi, @Luis Sandoval --

You mention the influences in a country that could affect how optimistic people are.  What could these influences be?  And, why are Brazil and Mali's optimism so low?  

How do what youth and adults think about the world compare?  What patterns do you notice?

name: Andrew
comment info:
Title: Boomers are a Downer!

This graph shows that, at a global level, young people are more optimistic about the world than older people.  There are a few places where - by a narrow margin - older people are more positive, but it is more common for young people to be substantially more optimistic.  Japan and the US stand out as having round about a 40% gap between proportions of young and old saying the world is getting better.  This is an interesting counterpoint to many discourses around generational attitudes: especially the notion that GenZ is somehow more 'cynical', and also the evidence that the younger generation has a much worse time than the baby boomers when it comes to job security and home ownership prospects.

replies.name: F
replies.comment info:
@Andrew
I think you bring up a good point. I do find it interesting when you talk about generational attitudes. I think that despite having a more difficult time, maybe new generations are more than ever willing for fight for change.
